title: The Vinewood Parable
shortSummary: Ezekiel 15 uses the metaphor of the useless vinewood to illustrate the worthlessness of Jerusalem’s inhabitants due to their sin. God declares that just as the vinewood is fit only for burning, so will He judge Jerusalem by fire for their trespasses, leading to desolation.
timeline: c. 593 BC - Early Babylonian Exile, during Ezekiel’s prophetic ministry

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: A prophet of God who delivers God's messages to the people of Israel, including the parable in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Son of man
keyCharacters.description: A title used by God to address Ezekiel, emphasizing his humanity and prophetic role.

keyCharacters.name: Inhabitants of Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: The people of Jerusalem who are being judged by God for their sin and rebellion.

definitions.definition: A grapevine, often used symbolically in Scripture; here it represents something with limited practical use apart from its fruit.
Material used to feed a fire; in this chapter, the vinewood is only fit to be burned as fuel, symbolizing judgment.
Sin or violation of God’s law; the reason given for God’s judgment on Jerusalem.
A biblical expression meaning to oppose or bring judgment upon someone.

outline.heading: God’s Question about the Vine Tree
outline.description: God asks Ezekiel to consider the nature of the vine tree compared to other trees, highlighting its limited usefulness apart from its fruit.

outline.heading: The Vinewood’s Worthlessness for Work
outline.description: The vinewood is described as only suitable for burning, emphasizing its uselessness for any practical purpose, symbolizing the people’s spiritual state.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment on Jerusalem
outline.description: God declares that just as the vinewood is given to the fire, so the inhabitants of Jerusalem will be given over to judgment and desolation because of their sin.

application: Recognize that without bearing fruit for God, believers are of little spiritual value and must examine their lives for genuine faith and obedience.
Understand that God’s judgment is certain for unrepentant sin, urging believers to repent and seek His mercy while there is opportunity.
Trust in God’s righteous justice even when facing trials, knowing that He is sovereign over the fate of nations and individuals.
Commit to living a life that honors God’s purpose, avoiding spiritual uselessness and striving to be fruitful in service and holiness.

keyVerses.text: Behold, it is cast into the fire for fuel; the fire devoureth both the ends of it, and the midst of it is burned. Is it meet for any work?
keyVerses.significance: This verse vividly illustrates the uselessness of the vinewood, symbolizing the spiritual worthlessness of Jerusalem’s inhabitants apart from God’s grace.

keyVerses.text: Therefore thus saith the Lord GOD; As the vine tree among the trees of the forest, which I have given to the fire for fuel, so will I give the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
keyVerses.significance: God’s declaration of judgment connects the metaphor directly to Jerusalem, showing the certainty of their punishment for sin.

keyVerses.text: And I will set my face against them; they shall go out from one fire, and another fire shall devour them; and ye shall know that I am the LORD, when I set my face against them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes God’s active opposition to sin and the resulting consequences, affirming His holiness and justice.
